comment: Caramel sweetness with a lot of fruity flavor on the palate. Vanilla and fruit on the long finish.

Smoith as butter with a really nice burbon finish. I love a good wiskey and this is a great blend of Scottish dram and Kentucky freel. I had 2 bottles and i literally drank one bottle in 2 nights. Great.
I like my Scotch neat, this one wasn't as smooth. It wasn't bad, but you can taste the bourbon in there.

Tasted at The Bluebird Inn, Cornwall, PA. Nose grins up at you with sweet, bright, fragrant apple and caramel. Bold (almost Irish) vanilla carries into the palate with oak and a touch of hot menthol. Drying finish, some cinnamon, woody and a bit resinous, but in a pleasant, satisfying way. A cheerful, mellow-bourbon-like experience.

Vanilla and apples on the nose. More of the same on the palate. Rich, smooth, and fruity. A little dark chocolate on the finish. Kind of non-descript, lots of bourbon character. Nice at a bar but don't need to buy. Spend the money on an actual bourbon instead.
Subtle sweet BBQ notes. Oaked finish.

Really like this one, don't be turned off by the Glenfiddich power house, this one is nicely crafted and in my opinion a steal at $49 for what I get. Very sweet, with lots of sweet baked apple, medium finish, wonderful aromas that indeed remind me of a well crafted bourbon but with the distinct character of a single malt (no confusion here, it does NOT taste or smell like a bourbon but it share some elements). Reminders me a little of a Balvenie but stronger and tastier. 3 drops of water nicely opens it. I will come back later as the bottle changes...
tried in the vegas airport, liked it

Nose - Sweet vanilla, green apples, hint of cherry, ripe bosc pears, a cereal sweetness like that of Honey Smacks cereal.
Taste - Vanilla brown sugar sweetness, very buttery/oily mouthfeel, cinnamon heat, lightly bitter like if you burnt an apple peel.
Finish - Lingering cinnamon warmth, lightly bitter orange pith, muted candied orange peel, light bitter oak like that you get from an oaked chardonnay.
82/100

I think I could drink this every day of the year.  Sweetness of the wood and a bit of vanilla add to the typical single malt characteristics.  Complex enough, but not overbearing.  A Scotch for every day.
Wonderful unique nose.  Full and dense with sweet bourbon flavors.  A very enjoyable and easy drinking scotch.

Truthfully, I figured this one would be crass marketing more than good whisky, but I will admit - this is a solid offering from Glenfiddich, and (for me) an improvement on the classic malt. The nose was really restrained when I sampled this - some vanilla, spice, and a bit of toasted wood. Palate-wise, the classic Glenfiddich pear note is here, but swirled with creamy vanilla, baking spices, ginger, and white pepper, with a long, beautiful poached pear ending. I'll happily drink this.

My first impression is that this is just like the Glenfiddich finished in IPA casks. It seemed more like marketing than anything else. Not as much bourbon character here on the first few sips. After my pallette adjusted, I could get the bourbon notes underneath the smokey scotch.
I am new to drinking scotch, I have been enjoying this occasionally.
Would like to give this 3.5. Sampled at ABC. Not bad, but I prefer a little more spice/burn.

Not an overdone char like Johnny double black but definitely there. An overall solid scotch and probably great if you're really into the char/bourbon crossover. I'm more of a traditionalist but this is a good move for them in the American market.
Honey and licorice.  Very sweet with a bit of burn.
You can smell and taste the honey
Beautiful scotch. Sweeter with caramel notes.
Very good. Oaky at the finish. Good lingering oak taste. Not smoky. Best tasting scotch for the money
Delicious, my favorite from Glenfiddich so far
A very smooth dram. Can't wait now to try the 19 year old Age of Discovery bourbon version.
Rather smooth, better than the taliskar 10. Dry and easy finish. Would recommend.
bottle kill - hint of peat, vanilla, oak, not long lasting

Smells like... bourbon. Vanilla, oak, some orchard fruit. Silky on the tongue, some caramel... then you quickly realize this is scotch, not bourbon. Malt flavors, some bitterness, oak, fruit, and a slight medicinal flavor at the end. Nice warmth. Apart from the great nose and the wood notes, not as bourbony as I was expecting, but I was probably looking for too much. This is a pleasant pour, not quite an easy sipper for me given the level of bitterness (not overwhelming, just a bit more than I prefer). A great one to try with buddies during a whisk(e)y tasting. 3/14/17

It seems Glenfiddich spent some time in the Bourbon country, either that or this is Glenfiddich's cousin from the states visiting the Speyside region.

On the nose you immediately get the soft bourbon sweetness you'd expect. Sweet corn undertones and hints of dried mango and fruits.

Body is more like a bourbon than a Speyside, that is, more viscous than smooth.

Finish starts off subtle then expands at the very end for a very non spey finish.

If you're a fan of Glenfiddich and bourbons, this is an interesting single malt to try. It's a niche, but it accomplished what it set out to do.
Very smooth scotch. Vanilla caramel. Tasty.

Glenfiddich doesn't move me the way Ardbeg or Laphroaig do, but I came away from this drink with warm feelings.  The stated purpose of this scotch was to merge some bourbon flavors with Glenfiddich, and it's exactly as advertised.  It would be a strong gateway or transitional drink for a bourbon drinker trying to get into scotch, or vice versa.  It has a much lighter and maltier character than any bourbon, but the top notes are honey, toffee, and vanilla, more so than any of the usual fruit notes from Glenfiddich.  It may be an unfortunate consequence of having this after the intensity of a cask strength Booker's, but I didn't detect a lot of unique notes here.  The additional two years of age does help smooth this out compared to Glenfiddich 12, and it's not much of a price bump at a reasonable $50 a bottle.  If Glenfiddich 12 and 14 were the only two bottles on the shelf, I'd opt for this one for the extra $10-15.
Tasted very much like I'd imagined it would. Think glenfiddich with a fuller body and smoky, slightly sweet notes. Delicious

This scotch is true to its emphasis on the "bourbon" aspect of its nature. On the nose, there is Jolly Rancher apple candy, maple syrup, brown sugar, lemon and orange, while on the pallet there is the bourbon'ish note of vanilla, without the sweetness. The finish is likewise vanilla. This is one of my favorite scotches, which retails for around $42 (750ml).
Excellent dark chocolate and dark cherry notes. The fruitiness up front is bold, and the bourbon stays with you the whole time you taste. Wonderful, strong flavor.
One of my favorite scotches! I will keep a bottle in my collection as long as possible
sample/possibly the sweetest Scotch I've tried; irresistible   second sample: a little less appealing, maybe 3.5 rating, value of 12 year ($15-20 less) more apparent

$50. Highly rated for the price. A good one to buy a bottle and try. 
Bought a bottle 9/5/17 at Ralphs. $50.
Very good. No bitter after taste at all.

At 14 years, this is an amazing scotch for the money. On the nose you'll immediately find fresh melon, honey, and ripe fruit. There's a harder to find but definable sweet note, displaying candy and tropical hues. I got banana and wood upon first contact. That's all mixed with a mild heat to get your salivary glands working over time. It's only on the finish that you detect baking spices and walnut. 

This one is has something for everyone to love at some point along the journey. 

(FWF share #33)
Opened: 08/24/17
Finished: 05/18/18

Expert tasting notes are accurate. Complex enough and enjoyable. I like the extra char, but am not a big fan of Glenfiddich in general. This is the best I've had in the line, but I will be finishing it to make room on my shelf for something else.
Very good flavor. A little sweet for my pallet.

if you aren't a fan of their 12 yr give this one a try.  wow what a fusion of memories and mellowness.  there's so much scotch and bourbon marriage going on that I'm just so at ease.  I don't know what it is about the scent it's so relaxing.  I had a lot of bourbons before ultimately preferring scotch after being introduced to Glenlivet and I dunno, something about this nose brings back every single good vibe I've ever had at whisky tastings or sharing whisky with friends.  It's just all at once it's overwhelming.  I bought fifth on a whim which is unlike me but I gotta say damn.  This is fantastic.  If i could sum it up in one sentence: great bourbon nose, great scotch taste.
Not a bad whisky, but if I want to drink bourbon I'll drink bourbon.  If I want to drink scotch I'll drink scotch.  Trying to get the best of both worlds in a single bottle just doesn't work for me.
Sherry cask added a hint of sweetness of Sherry. Balanced with a bit of sweetness which make the whiskey more unique. Fluently and easy to drink.

I’ve had this several times before but for some reason never wrote a review. I get apples and caramel on the nose, along with maple syrup.  

Tastes like I’m biting into a nice fluffy berry muffin. The bourbon influence is really nicely balanced here, and being a huge bourbon fan, I’m really enjoying this.  

This one is weird but after chewing on it for a bit trying to pinpoint the familiar taste I was experiencing, my mind flashed back to being a kid eating cookie dough off of a spoon. I love how whiskey can do that.  

Not my favorite thing ever, but really nice, pleasant, and somehow comforting. Will keep this one in the collection from now on!
Easy to drink, with good flavor and scent. Smooth finish, with little lingering burn.
David B. gave me this for Christmas 2017. Nice smooth taste.
Vanilla but not too sweet, nice

Nose: spiced and honey almonds, oatmeal cookies, oak.
Taste: Sweet apple cobbler, molasses Oatmeal after.

Very enjoyable. Its dessert, a treat to finish the night on.
just took my first few sips. just enough spice! Butterscotch in a glass. loving it so far.
Rich green fruit nose of pear and Granny Smith apples. Toffee and vanilla come in to seal the deal in both nose and taste. Bites a bit, but water soothes. A mainstay on my shelf
Opens with green apples, hay, citrus zest and tropical fruits. Then follows toffee, custard, berries. Very pleasant. This is probably my favorite unpeated single malt so far.

Honestly, this malt was truly surprising.  All of the flavors are subdued, but it works well. Red apple and vanilla are consistent from the nose through the palate. Milk chocolate also makes an appearance after a while. Towards the end, you do get a touch of smoke which continues throught the finish, but the finish is dominated by cinnamon and cloves. Apples and chocolate are still there but not as prevalent.
sweet and malty, delicious. rich, vanilla notes.

scotch for people who prefer bourbon. a bit too far toward bourbon for my taste, but a pleasanr dram. oak and honey on nose. taste shows quality barrel aging. heavy mouthfeel. more than just bourbon/scotch blend, much smoother than glenfiddich 12. good addition to collection
Bottle was gift from Eric Andresen

Nose:  oak, sweet, vanilla, apple
Palate: mild spice, oak, vanilla, sweet, malt, mildly fruity
Finish:  oak, mild spice, sweet, light vanilla
Light and smooth.  It definitely blends scotch and bourbon flavors without being overly spicy or vanilla.

Smooth 14 year scotch, with a hint of bourbon. I like it a lot. Its like you had a glass of blantons and then poured a scotch without cleaning the glass. Very smooth and just an after taste of bourbon.
Subtle sweet with light smoke. A nice scotch but not as sweet as a bourbon
Perfect transition for a bourbon drinker to scotch.
Carmel and vanilla. Kentucky meets speyside.
Vanilla and caramel but not too sweet. Clear Oak and spice in the taste with a sweet and light finish.
Get it again. Great flavor full body nice fruitiness but less scotch more bourbon
The flavor profile is right on point. Lots of vanilla and caramel. Very smooth. Easy to drink.
Love the bourbon qualities without being too sweet and having a dry finish. Just a nice balanced whiskey of sweet, smoke and spice

My new favorite scotch. Glenfiddich absolutely outdid themselves with this one. This is the perfect blend of vanilla and caramel on the nose partnered with the delicious combo of vanilla and that Glenfiddich butterscotch on the palate. If I ever go into a coma, please put a pour of this into my IV and I’ll immediately come back asking for seconds. If you haven’t tried this yet, and I could not stress this enough, you’re missing out on a gem of a whisky.
not peaty at all, but full whiskey flavor.
One of the finest I had
Sweet - more than expected, not overly. The usual with a dry component of bourbon and oak. My new daily sipper.
Fresh malted grain, cereal, white chocolate, a little too sweet
Woody. Creamy. No peat. Sweetness on the nose. Tannins on the finish.
Sweet nose. Vanilla, honey, pear on the taste. Moderate complexity and finish. Nice, light daily sipper or aperitif. A good value at $50 USD
This is fruit forward scotch that through the journey of tasting is desperately trying to be a bourbon and it is awesome
When u have to tell her u can’t do 3 nights in a row! (Ok, she told u...)

Big fan of this one. The barrel finishing adds a good amount of smoke, toffee, and some orange to the strong flavors of orchard fruits you tend to get in a Speyside. It's not too light or honey-sweet, but not too dark and syrup/bourbon-sweet either.
Thick and slurpy texture to it. Brown sugar on the nose. A bit of nuttiness.
Definitely taste the bourbon influence and the sweetness.
carmelized toasted barrel notes on nose. once an ice cube is added, sweet floral notes with warm spices abound. warm wood finish.

Nose has notes of caramel.

Light burn, sweet notes similar to brown sugar. Warm finish.

Opens up more with spice notes when an ice cube is added.
A very nice, easy, go to choice for scotch.

Today is 12/5/18. 85 years ago today in 1933 the 21's Amendment was ratified ending Prohibition.

I am on a Scotch kick... so I decided to sample my bottle of Glenfiddich 14, which is finished in New American Oak barrels. 

Color: Pale gold

Nose: Caramel, green apple, cinnamon, dustyness, oak, a touch of maple.

Pallet: Caramel, honey, oak spice grows, green apple sourness,

Finish: Sweetness, malt, oak, char, slightly astringent medium-short length
Like apple pie, honeied tea, and some oak tannins. it's delicious.
Pleasing nose, smooth a little oily. No smoke👍

I can’t usually taste all the flavors described in the expert’s review but I was pleasantly surprised by this one. This is Slightly rosy in color and I get  the smells of vanilla and caramel. When tasting,  I  can vaguely notice the char but get good notes of what I think taste almost like green apple and a moderate finish. Overall, I would say this is an excellent scotch!
The nose...wow. Orchard fruit, caramel, barrel. The palette follows the nose, but added leather. Finish is quite pleasant, but not extremely long. It's delicious. It's really delicious.
Great richness, drinks above its price.
Faintly fruity but kind of spicy. Lots of aftertaste stimulus on the sides of tongue, mouth, and nose.
Delicious! Wonderfully smooth, mild spices, tasty sweetness, a little bourbon oaky character.  Well done.  Hard to drink slowly because you want to gulp it.
Blend of scotch and bourbon. Mild scotch w/sweet vanilla flavors and some spice and smoke
sweet. notes of bourbon. great way to convince a bourbon drinker to cross the pond

I have never had a scotch I like.  The nose is light, sweet and hints at bourbon.  Never would have guessed scotch from the nose.  Taste I can tell it’s scotch and it’s the best scotch I’ve ever had, but still not bourbon.  May be my first scotch bottle I buy.
Not peaty, very smooth, no burn almost too easy
Floral nose. Pepper finish.  A decent dram.  I think GF 12 is better for the $
Very approachable for a bourbon drinker.  Caramel on the nose.  Dry finish.  Not much alcohol bite.  Nice sipper, maybe even a little flat.
Extremely smooth with vanilla notes and a slight pete on the back end.
Excellent Scotch for those that enjoy both Bourbon and Scotch!
Very nice. Smooth. Easy drinking. Fresh fruit, oak, fresh smoke (if that makes sense), medium length. Great whisky, especially for the price.
Rich and vanilla, very similar to smoother bourbon. Spicy.

This is amazing to me.  If you pour and sip, I get apples/pears and vanilla primarily and really nothing special.  However, the same drink becomes magical after a half hour in the glass.  It changes more than anything else I’ve ever had and becomes almost entirely 
different.  I get apple-buttery biscuits and vanilla with some oak and it’s truly one of my favorites.  Do yourself a favor and let this open for 20 minutes.
Sweet, vanilla, spicy, silky, smooth... a keeper!
Very mild on the taste with vanilla and slight appley citrus. The apple is much stronger on the nose.

Nose:  Oh  so much. Honey, apple, hay, oak, almonds, toast, pair, slight cinnamon and cream.

Taste: Sweet apple, honey, bear claw pastry,  molasses, burnt cookies, ending in a woody and waxy walnut.

Experience:  A cool fall day at golden hour. The sun is just about set and everything is lit with a warm glow, you pick up a walnut or pecan (you cant tell) on your stroll home through crisp leafs. The air is sweet with many meals and treats being cooked in doors, before you step inside to the warmth of home you take a deep breath of perfection. Not the chill of winter or the sticky sweet of summer, but the round comfort of fall.  

*Note: This was my first  ever Scotch purchase. It was love at first sip, I wanted to give it another go now that my taste has developed.  I have had the chance to try and own much more expensive, old, and rare whiskys, but for the price, this might be one of the best. Don't get me wrong there are better, but I've paid 2-3 times what this bottle costs and came up short. Get it if you want to raise your bar of what quality scotch is.
This is a nice scotch for more special occasions if the price is right. A little better than the 12 but I certainly prefer the 15.
Sweet goodness. Loads of flavors of nose and rich palate
Sweet goodness from the barrels. My favorite scotch from the bourbon barrel experiments. Glad this is permanent in the Glennfiddich line.

Tons on wood on the nose vanilla is also present 
The taste has strong vanilla but the new charred oak barrel makes its presence known! Carmel also I’m in their as well but the finish is all  new charred barrel rather than an alcohol burn.

Nose: 
orange peel, vanilla, apples, some spices in there,  pear ,slight smokey note at the end.

palate: 
citrus note at the front opens up to spice and apples. after sitting in the palate for a minute or two I get a small kick of smoke and peat at the very end. 

overall great bottle and I like that it's bottled at 43%. I don't think you can go wrong with this if you want a whiskey that's  interesting but not overly peated or smokey.

Nose: floral, 
Palate: spicy, 
Finish: vanilla

This whisky has such richness and complexity, and it’s mostly because of the maturation. It’s been aged in Kentucky bourbon barrels and finished in American New Oak barrels from Kelvin cooperage in Kentucky. This gives it the richness that a lot of bourbons have. It doesn’t have barrel bite like bourbons do, but the barrel richness is very much there. While the barrel imparts vanilla flavors in bourbon, it imparts char notes in this. And it perfectly compliments the classic fruit flavors in Glenfiddich. Plus, the 14 years allows these flavors to harmonize quite beautifully. The char notes are quite spectacular. I highly recommend this to any fan of whisky.
Bourbon taste comes through makes it very sweet. More vanilla than oak

tasty. has the bourbon bite up front but also the mash sweetness. finished with a fruity scotch at 14, which is well worth the $40-50 price point. this will easily slot into the rotation of regularly sipped bottles.

absolutely amazing this is definitely something I would keep stocked at all times on my bar for the $50 - $60 price tag.

Nose - 5/5 smells like something straight out of the bruichladdich distillery. Malted barley, apples, pears, applewood smoked bacon, campfire hits in the rear, very little peat.

Palate - 4.5/5 Sour apples, Belgium waffles?, light tobacco, pears, Moss, slight peat, mint.

Price 4.5/5 bought on sale for $50
Definitely fruit on the nose and smooth toffee on the palate. Finishes with a bite on the oak.
Lots of vanilla, fruit, spices, and oak. Bit of a warming burn on finish.
Hardly any smoke. Smooth. Easy to drink. Lightly sweet
Nice, smooth, hint of bourbon, warm on the finish!
Best on the rocks. Not great neat.
Perfect balance and a close 5 star...not too sweet with honey and apples on the palate.  The finish is medium in length and goes down smooth with a hint of oak, vanilla and spice.

Liquor rep visit
 Smells sweet but slightly salty, tastes a little on the alcohol forward side with a heavier oak char
Surprisingly much bolder and more complex than the already enjoyable 12 year. A deeper combination of oak, vanilla, citrus, and nutmeg with a mild spice and and earthy balance.

Sweet vanilla nose that is quickly replaced by a bit of a boozy sting, then comes the rich oak. 

The taste, more oak with a very long finish with a nice smoke at the end!

With how modern family life is these days, we find ourselves having to really make an effort to ensure we have dedicated time, unplugged to reconnect. For my family we have a big spread in ages of our children (7-20 yrs old) so we have all commit to a Sunday dinner where they all participate in making dinner, eating together and then cleaning up! My job is to ensure all ingredients are in stock (chicken marsala this week) so off I went to my local grocery store. As one does, I always peruse the Whiskey aisle and happened to notice this one on sale for $38.99. I'd had my eye on it for a long while and figured it would make a great grill companion grilling the veggies. 
My hesitation had always been that I am not typically a fan of Bourbon only maturation on non Peated Scotch and to be honest I am not the biggest fan of Glenfiddich 12, 15 or really the 18 for the $$. However l, under $40 let's roll the dice! Let's see if it was money well spent:

On the palette it's surprisingly rich and almost oily with big orchard fruits (apricots mainly), butterscotch, cereal malt with a dash of honey buttered toast. Vanilla becomes more evident on the mid palette with toffee and some spice. The Finish is a medium length with more fruit, malt and dark honey and brown sugar notes. Lovely dram!

Now this is not all that complex at all but what it does it does incredibly well. Glenfiddich did an outstanding job of showcasing Bourbon matured Speyside and not straying from that objective. For the price point it's a really great deal. I for one will be adding this one as a Scotch I will always keep on hand. 

Cheers all and here's to another week!
This is the standard for straight up scotch whiskey. This is a staple for my drinks cupboard.
It hits a middle ground between a bourbon and a scotch. Was easy to get into as a bourbon drinker looking to experience more scotches.

In the summer my preferences turn toward bourbon. I prefer the sweeter dram over ice rather than Scotch’s drier, smoky profile. I bought this with the Glenglassaugh Evolution looking for a sweeter Scotch for summer sipping. The Glenglassaugh fits the bill. This is also a pretty decent summer whisky, but not quite as good as the Evolution. 

This expression from Glenfiddich is aged for 14 years and finished in new charred American oak. In theory this should add some bourbon characteristics to the final product. I’d have to say it succeeds. It’s bottled at 43% ABV, is a medium gold color in the glass, and forms a few quick forming legs when given a swirl. 

The nose is sweet grassy barley. The bourbon influence is very noticeable: vanilla and caramel behind the malt. Just a touch of burn, but for a 14 year old malt @ 43% it’s a little much. Water had no appreciable affect on the nose. 

In the mouth it’s sweet honeyed orchard fruits, and buttery malt with a thick mouthfeel. Again, water doesn’t seem to have much effect. 

The medium finish is sweet malt with a hint of smoke and pepper. There’s an odd sour note after everything else fades, or maybe it’s just me. This is the one aspect that water affects: Water seems to extend the finish. 

Overall for $40 this is a good deal. A 14 yr old age-stated Scotch for under $40? Yessir! Good but not great. 3.5/5.0.

For the money this is a very fine whisky. Here in PA, the 12 year standard is $50 and this 14 year Bourbon Barrel Reserve is only $8 more...a complete no-brainer.  I actually first tasted it, as I often do with non-exotic priced liquor, with a snack, either a sandwich or some cheese and bread/crackers. This delivers wonderfully  sweet fruitiness on the nose and in the mouth. At sip, a warm bit of spicey on the inner cheek and tongue combines with a fruity sweetness. I get everything from peachy/mango to coconut with this one. The finish at swallow is medium and there is a lingering aftertaste of sweet long after. I'm thinking certain kinds of hard candy, the really good tinned English/French stuff. And yes, there is also apple fruit, well after swallow. 

A wonderful bargain by a storied brand, though the less complex Irish Knappogue Castle gives it solid value competition for $15 less in PA.

$58 at the PLCB
Nose is quite earthy, grassy and almost hoppy. Very smooth. Burn comes on very late but is mild. Aftertaste is like exhaling a cigar
A gift from Justin bc of Elowen’s birth.

Nose: Vanilla, Carmel, Malt, Barrel Spice, 
Apple, Honey

Taste: Carmel Toffee, Vanilla, Honey, Apple, Oak, Rich, Slight Ash
Plum, fig, various mixed fruits, vanilla, toffee, licorice, and molasses.  No smoke or peat, but some oak.
Nice and sweet. Nothing special though

This 14 year-old Glenfiddich was the first whisky I ever purchased that I'd consider "beyond entry level." At the time it seemed like a big step up from anything I'd tried previously. I'm excited to see how this ranks now that I've got a proper basis for comparison.

Nose: Classic speyside with a couple bourbon notes. Vanilla, toffee, caramel, orange, honey, orchard fruits (apple, pear) and apricot. Some cereal grains and oak spice to round it out. Very malty, light spice. Over time, a banana note emerges, as well as the cola note I usually only get in bourbons.

Palate: Vanilla, caramel, apricot, apple pear, honey, milk chocolate, and orange. More of the big malt notes, but it seems more mature and refined here; none of that cereal grain. The oak is also more pronounced here. A bit of cinnamon and baking spice. Bourbon influence is apparent.

Finish: More of the same, fruity, floral notes. It's more of that apple, pear, apricot, orange until the oak and baking spices/cinnamon take over. Short-to-medium length finish. After an additional taste, I get a superb toasted oak note that really brings this up a notch for me.

Solid effort. Nothing too crazy. This is a nice cross between a Speyside fruit bowl and a touch of bourbon of influence. I'm enjoying it quite a bit. It hits all the right notes and it's balanced throughout.

Factoring great VFM, I think 4 stars is fair. If my memory serves me correct, this may be my favorite Glenfiddich I've had to date, regardless of price point. Well-balanced. Glad this one holds up for me. If you're a fan of the classic Speyside profile, you're in for a treat with this one. Well done, Glenfiddich.

Bumped it up to a 4.25 on subsequent tasting. Had a couple more times and have really been digging it. Awesome stuff.
A picture of Homer Simpson drooling would capture my reaction to tasting this. Mmmm, bourbon cask scotch. Delicious!

A bit of caramel, cream, and vanilla oak with an interesting, dusty oat note underneath. There is some sweet notes of apples with some faint cinnamon. The palate is really smooth, with the apple spice sweetness and oak forming the foundation. There is a flash of bright fruits, particularly raspberry, before it darkens up with molasses and some char rolling in to tamp down the sweeter elements. The oak and barrel notes finish the experience, with the worn used oak and the new oak bouncing off each other to see which one can have the last word. Ultimately the worn, slightly dry oak has the last breath as the apple and vanilla also give one last appearance.

A marriage of bourbon and scotch. Forward taste of sweet vanilla, toffee and charred brown sugar. Lingering finish with a mild burn. Still forming an opinion on this but it’s unique and pretty good for a glenfiddich.
I did enjoy this single malt yet oddly enough I prefer the 12 year to this.

Im a fan of the Deanston Virgin oak so been looking at this one for a while. $41 on sale so had to go for it. Poured neat, nose brings bananas foster, malt and spicy oak. 86 proof is higher than some other Glenfidds but deep inhales are unencumbered by ethanol. Palate is lots of sweet vanilla, caramel and rich malt bolstered by the spicy oak. Carries a little sizzle and heat but the deep flavor is worth it. Has a kind of cream soda vibe to it. Finishes with fading malty vanilla, cinnamon oak and char. This is another candidate for bourbon guys looking for a scotch. Plenty for the scotch lovers too. Its got robust malt, good sweetness and strong barrel char influence all with a 14yr age statement(though it drinks like a 12). I think this is a tasty albeit hot single malt........86/100.......better than the 12 yr but the 15 and 18 are cut above

For me, this is kind of the gold standard and one of my two primary whiskies.  The nose is quintissential Scotch in it’s purist form...one whif is like coming home (though I tend to inhale a number of times before moving on to the initial sip).  And on the tongue, just delightful...probably the easiest drinking and most satisfying whisky you’ll ever find.  It’s Speyside all the way (no smoke to be found) with lovely notes of barley and vanilla, and just enough bite bottled at 43% to give it all the body and character you could want.  When I’m in the mood for a Highland Scotch with a little smoke, I go with Glenmorangie Quinta Ruban 14 or Highland Park 12...but alternating between those and this one is just about all I’d ever need (not that I’ll stop sampling new drams...ever!).  To give you a further idea how good this is, it replaced Macallan 15 Fine Oak in my bar when the price on that one shot up so dramatically...and frankly, I don’t feel like I’m missing out on anything at all.  Highly recommended.

Got this at a bar in SAT. Small cocktail glass. Nose is scotch with hints of sweet red apple. I also get brown sugar. The taste is barley with some red apple and brown sugar. Fits nicely in my idea of Speyside.

I want to try this again on a cleaner palate. Will purchase again.

Sweet, but not overly. Overall it’s very nice to sip. It’s smooth and has a good amount of flavor. I was hoping for something close to the Glenmoragie Nector Dor but this doesn’t quite line up.  There’s a sweetness Nector Dor has that I haven’t been able to match.  This reminds me of Aberlour 16 but it doesn’t have any of the floral taste Aberlour 16 has which makes it better to me (I’m not a fan of the floral taste.)
Smooth and light.  Clear bourbon influence.   Easy drinking!   Delicious!

Color is gold, medium to low viscosity, chill-filtered. Nose is medium strength, with hints of raisins, toffee, vanilla, and ripe fruit. Palate is rich and round, with notes of fruit, caramel, toffee, and oak. Bourbon barrel influence is definitely there but it is not overwhelming. Finish is short but nice with oaky and fruity notes and a touch of bitterness. A few drops of water in this 43% ABV dram opens more fruit flavors and rounds up the pallet, finish looses its bitterness. Overall a very nice and complex dram.

Tonight I'm drinking the Glenfiddich 14 Year Bourbon Barrel Reserve Single Malt. This was actually the first scotch I ever tried, so thank you to my father for having good tastes. This scotch is a US-exclusive offering, meant to cater to our bourbon loving palates. And while it's not particularly bourbony, it brings some wonderful sweet bourbon vanilla to the playing field. I picked this one up at Bevmo with a coupon for $36.99 and wish I could consistently buy it for that price. My detailed thoughts and rating below: ⠀
⠀
🥃 Glenfiddich 14 Year Bourbon Barrel Reserve - 43% ABV
⠀
Nose: Sweet honey, barley, and a little mint. Brown sugar and vanilla. Mellow apple fruitiness.
⠀
Taste: Barley, honey, sugar, and caramel. There's a nice cerealness to it. The apple notes are more subdued and are only present in more of a sweet apple pie flavor. The barrel influence comes through here much more than on the nose, through both vanillan and tannins. This is a fantastic desert whisky. It's like a spiced creme brulee whisky.

The texture is slightly oily and the finish is medium. Flavor-wise, the finish carries nice honey and fruit sweetness along with some tannins and baking spices and warmth. Im very much a fan of this whisky and it might be my favorite of their offerings that I've tried (12, 14, 15, and 18).
⠀
Current rating: 93/100

Light golden and medium body.

The nose is like apple cider, a pungent floral honey and cereal notes in the back.  Warm oak and tannins linger in the background.

Palate on the front is pretty typical Glenfiddich - dry, sun-dried oak, slight ethanol burn.  The back of the mouth picks up the vanilla and cream brûlée’ from the ex-bourbon barrels.  

All together still a single malt scotch with a faint amount of bourbon influence for me.  Not enough to draw away a bourbon drinker I’m afraid.  I’d like to believe the ex-bourbon is more of a four roses like influence with some sour and spice.  That said, still not enough comes through to make me think “bourbon!”  

The finish is floral and relatively short and dry for me.  As a Glinfiddich fan I say it’s a keeper but pour this for the single malt crowd.  Anyone hoping for a rich, caramel, spicy dram will be left disappointed.
Too much bourbon, not enough scotch. It's an interesting idea, but I'd rather just have one or the other.
Too much bourbon, not enough scotch. It's an interesting idea, but I'd rather just havhave
Very sweet, can definitely taste the malt, delicious!
Very sweet. Cross between scotch, bourbon, and Irish whiskey. Definitely like
Quite yummy. I love the vanilla notes that come out.
Sweet on the nose, with a relatively smooth honey after taste.

Not sure why, maybe it's the oxidation that does it, but this was the last dram of the bottle and, to me, the best dram.    Everything smoothed out a bit.  Almost like a few drops of water were added. I actually got a little more of all the notes.  I love how this lovely liquid changed as I progressed through the bottle.  This was money well spent.  Regardless the whiskey, I learn something with each tipple.
It’s good, but I should have had it BEFORE the Santa Teresa, not after.
Full and smooth with vanilla, toffee, and spice. Clean finish with oak.
anise seed, soap, white bread, apples.

Aroma 6, 6
Taste 7, 8
Body 8, 9
Finish 7, 9

Little smoky

1st sip:Spicier up front than I was expecting.  Lingering taste.  Overall smooth.  Added just a little water with this dram.
3rd sip: now the different flavors are coming through.  Toffee, vanilla.
Was excited when I got a bottle but not what I was hoping for in taste. Being a scotch and bourbon lover this missed for me.

Again, this is very sweet but packs more of a bite than it’s older brothers. I love how long the taste lingers on the palate. I wouldn’t seek a bottle of this out, but I very much enjoyed the taste I was able to have tonight.

The sweetness of the bourbon barrels are really noticeable, and blew my mind when I first tried it! 

I could recommend this to anybody who likes a great scotch!
Was hyped up heavily before trying. Thought it was okay, nothing special. Good kick to it.
I tried liking this, but it was too sweet for me -- as if a tablespoon of sugar was put in it. Don't get me wrong, it's not bad... but not great either.
Nose is rich vanilla, caramel and brown sugar. Some oak and mushy apple. Smooth with a little spice. Sweet toffee and vanilla come through. Fruity finish.
Really pulls out those rich bourbon flavors of caramel and vanilla.

I had been hesitant to try this one. The barrel aging process sounded very similar to Glinlivet Founders, and I had been disappointed in that one. However Ctrexman posted a recent positive review. I am sure that Ct and I could have different preferences in our whisky, but I have NEVER found any disagreement with his tasting notes. (In fact, his palate is more attuned than mine.) Cutting to the chase, I found it on sale for $35 and plunged ahead. Nose and palate are very similar. Both show caramel, vanilla, hint of fruity light brown sugar, malt, a little spice, and a small touch of biscuit. It has a nice, soft mouthfeel and very little burn. I would describe the finish as medium; and, if you wait for it a slight astringency at the very end of the finish. I think that comes from the oak. Overall this is a very tasty Scotch that many would not recognize as a true "Scotch," much less as a single malt. A good Scotch to introduce to newbies, and particularly those who don't want the peat reek.
Delicious neat or with ice ball.  Extremely smooth with some woodsy sweetness from the bourbon barrel.  One of my favorites.
Smoke upfront, strong oak throughout, lingering bourbon feel.
It's good!  Good neat, a flavorful sip-er.
Decent scotch.  It's the foundation of my infinity bottle.  Nothing too complex and exciting.

Nose: heavy oak, caramel, vanilla
Palate: fairly thin, oak, spices, not particularly sweet; easy drinking
Finish: medium length, oaky

So good. Smooth. 
Better than the 15 and cheaper!

Oaky on the nose. Very smooth, no burn until swallow even then is minimal yet lingering. Light notes of Carmel and dried fruit. It finishes with a bourbon after taste and tingles your tongue. Interesting bottle
Interesting... Not a bottle but a nice glass

Smells similar to JW Black Label right out of the bottle. Very sweet flavor that reminds me a bit of cognac. Gonna have to drink more to get a real solid feel for it. I like it but don't love it at this point. Has a slight spice to it with a nice after taste.

This is my first real foray into the world of scotch, and I have to say, I'm impressed!  Being a bourbon guy, I went for a Speyside, easy "starter scotch" with bourbon influence, and this is absolutely stellar.  You get the bourbon right away on the nose and it carries over to the palate.  Creamy and sweet with a distinct chocolate Tootsie Roll note that keeps me coming back.  I don't see myself venturing too much further into scotch, but this may be a new staple around the house!  Oh and a $5 rebate, heck yeah...

Complex and smooth. Nose begins with creamy vanilla, then goes on to citrus and apples, some oakiness and hints of maltiness and spiciness; on the palate fruity, with green apples and citrus notes, hint of nuts shows up, even smoke from the charred barrels, very creamy and clingy; long finish with oakiness and nutiness. A lovely dram!
Rich and sweet with a bit of heat on the back end. Leaves a vanilla taste in the mouth.

honey,  cereal forward on the taste with short, semi- dry finish. light on the fruit flavor. At first it reminded me more of a scotch finished in sherry casks.   The more I drank,  the more a young bourbon came out. Finally got cinnamon on the aftertaste.  My palate has been off lately

Reasonable price for a fine whiskey.
One of my favorites. I usually buy this products if I cannot make a decision to buy.
Drinks more like a bourbon than a scotch. Sweet, mellow, lasting sweetness that begins as toffee and wood
Spicy and sweet. Notes of apple.
An easy sipper.  Compared to the 12 this one has more depth, a longer finish, and overall more enjoyable.
I get a lot of this oaky sweet vanillia, got some fruit for taste. A fantastic drink to sip on! Recommend it on the rocks or one ice cube.
Lots of bourbon notes. Best scotch to date.
Not too smooth to drink, immediate warm sensation on palate and with finish. Insufficient sweetness or flavor, did not appreciate fruity or floral tones on nose or palate
Glenfiddich Bourbon Barrel is a whisky I can always count on for a very satisfying taste. It has not let me down!
Fresh smell of apple carmel and vanilla. Very fresh smell of fresh cut apples. Very sweet taste of fruity apple and oak at first taste.

Sweet notes of caramel, vanilla and apples on the nose. Fruity notes as soon as it hits your palate with a slight aokiness to it, and a predominant apple aftertaste that lingers in your palate for a while. Fantastic scotch!
So smooth and full in the mouth
Lighter than most bourbons, very tasty
vanilla nise; spice, clove, orange, a bit of black licorice
Very sweet taste with notes of toffee and vanilla.
I tried it next to Buffalo Trace and I can see the comparison. I really enjoy it. Speyside isn’t quite as high as Highland or Islay on my list, but I’ll enjoy this one for a while.

It's quite good for what it is, but a bit too sweet for me. Love the nose - sweets from fruits and a bit of barley (I'm just learning what barley tastes/smells like). Palate: more of the same, but I was hoping it wouldn't be so sweet. Overall, very nice and will please many folk, as it is wonderfully balanced, etc., but, my mood at the moment says too sweet (but still enjoying).
A fan of most scotch from an ex bourbon cask, this is certainly no exception. Typical bourbon notes with a hint of white chocolate. A preferred house bottle.
nice scotch/bourbon mash-up; vanilla and caramel, slight black licorice at the end
Aggressive but great flavors. Good experience for an intermediate!
vanilla, as you would expect; green apple and sapling oak

Nose: Subtle hints of vanilla. Sweetness of sugar and fruit. Oaky as expected from a bourbon cask.

Palate: Sweet and smokey. Vanilla and caramel with some orange notes. Oaky taste is pleasant.

Finish: Longer than expected. Sugary sweetness lingers with some vanilla trailing behind.

Overall Thoughts: Deliciousness as expected from a Glenfiddich, admittedly a personal favorite. Sweetness goes a long way for me and this has a perfect blend of hearty and delicate flavor. I was gifted this bottle a few years ago by a Scottish friend and I’ll always be happy they introduced me to Glenfiddich.

I’m loving this one!! Such richness and spiciness.  I get wonderful complexity on the nose and right as I’m going to the palate I get the bourbon.  Long spicy warm finish.  The 43% abv is just enough power for this whisky, any lower and it would fall flat.  Best of both worlds.  When scotch meets bourbon and have a baby.  But make no mistake, this is definitely a single malt scotch whiskey!
Nose is sweet and malty with a rich almost buttery palate of malt and oak with a strong malty finish. For anyone who is wondering it’s fantastic in a highball
